headline.main: The Persistence of the Culture War

docs.abstract: The lack of common ground between left and right on abortion, same-sex marriage and contraception shows just how seriously we take these issues.
docs.snippet: The lack of common ground between left and right on abortion, same-sex marriage and contraception shows just how seriously we take these issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before he disappointed his many admirers by declining to seek the Republican nomination, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana told the Weekly Standard's Andrew Ferguson that the gravity of the economic and fiscal challenges facing America's next president might require calling a temporary "truce on the so-called social issues." On culture war controversies like abortion and same-sex marriage, he suggested, "we're going to just have to agree to get along for a little while."

docs.lead_paragraph: Ron Paul’s political views are unusual, and, as a closer look at his life reveals, unusually constant, shaping not only his career in Congress but also how he has lived his life.

headline.seo: For Ron Paul, a Distinctive Worldview of Long Standing
headline.main: Ron Paul’s Flinty Worldview Was Forged in Early Family Life
headline.print_headline: Ron Paul’s Flinty Worldview Was Forged in Early Family Life

docs.abstract: Interviews with Rep Ron Paul and scores of his relatives, friends and colleagues reveal that Paul's unusual political views were largely shaped by his early family life; Paul has held on to those views with unwavering fidelity, and they have directed not only his political career but also the way he lives his life (Series: The Long Run).
docs.snippet: Ron Paul’s political views are unusual, and, as a closer look at his life reveals, unusually constant, shaping not only his career in Congress but also how he has lived his life.

byline.contributor: Kitty Bennett and Kate Welsh contributed research.

docs.lead_paragraph: A golden retriever was the only thing that could reach a raging, disconnected boy.

headline.seo: Wonder Dog: A Golden Retriever Reaches a Raging Boy

docs.abstract: Melissa Fay Greene article describes how the family of Iyal Winokur, who struggled to deal with his developmental disabilities due to fetal alcohol syndrome, found relief by enlisting the help of 4 Paws For Ability, a nonprofit corporation that pairs the disabled with service dogs.
docs.snippet: A golden retriever was the only thing that could reach a raging, disconnected boy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Every few years, parents find new reasons to worry about their teenagers. And while there is no question that some kids continue to experiment with sex and substance abuse, the latest data points to something perhaps more surprising: the current generation is, well, a bit boring when it comes to bad behavior. By several noteworthy measures, today's teenagers are growing increasingly conservative. While marijuana use has recently had an uptick, teenagers are smoking far less pot than their parents did at the same age. In 1980, about 60 percent of high-school seniors had tried marijuana and 9 percent smoked it daily. Among seniors today, according to the University of Michigan's Monitoring the Future survey, which has tracked teenage risk behaviors since 1975, 45.5 percent have tried the drug and 6.6 percent are smoking it frequently ().

headline.main: The Kids Are More Than All Right

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column highlights research that shows that teenagers are growing increasingly conservative with respect to alcohol, tobacco and drug consumption and the likelihood that they have had sex or will get pregnant. Drawing, Charts (M)/
